response.answer_text: Answer: This is the approach I have used in presenting a thesis. The suggestions are pertinent for a research thesis in Humanities and Social sciences, and may not so relevant for STEMS thesis. Sufficient time allocated to write the thesis, but must not spent too much time writing a few chapters and neglect the other chapter. Written work must be properly edited. Useful to plan first what are to be written. Follow the plan closely. Then write a draft, put it away and return to improve it, edit and re-edit it. The whole thesis must be written like you are telling a story of your research work — you have spent a few years and invested much resources in researching a topic dear to you. Of not a story telling style but formal writing following the thesis guideline given to you by your school. Helpful to ask someone familiar with research in your research to read and critical it after you have written the thesis.In the introduction, the background to the research must be clearly written. The outline for each chapter is clearly presented. Likewise, the aim and objectives are clearly presented. The significance of the present tesearch is clearly noted. The writer’s research philosophy is made known. The structure of the research outline to be written is presented to offer the readers with a good overview of the research. A glossary of terms used in the thesis is succinctly defined and presented if offered.Have done a good literature review, proving you were very familiar with the related literature. Located the gap for your research. Use these effectively to develop the hypotheses if they are used. Pertinent notes from the literature review used, and correctly referenced. These notes are readily available for use in the writing process.Must ensure your work is well and formally written, where you strictly observed all the rules of grammar, with correct punctuations, and correct English expression in the language. No spoken English or colloquial used in the writing. Written sentences are kept relatively short so to not get yourself in a tangle in writing.The key areas presented are informative, succinctly and professionally discussed. There should be no patching! Each chapter must have an clear introduction and conclusion. Work must have section heads and within them paragraphing for new points in the discussion.Methodological approach used in the field work to collect the data is well-explained and its usage and its adoption for used, justified. The analysis is well discussed and findings clearly presented.The findings are clearly outlined, and are discussed, well supported by literature and where approriate underpinned by theories.Limitations of the current study are clearly stated, and recommendations for further research noted.A final conclusion chapter of the whole thesis is presented.Advise to keep copies of your written work safe in case in lose some of the completed work.

It all comes down to structure. If you structure your thoughts in a logical progression, your thesis will be strong. You'll know exactly where you need to do more research (if you do), and you'll be able to identify if there's a logical weakness in your argument (and then fix it, or simply acknowledge counter-arguements). Please read the answers here for the basics:Cecilia Sells' answer to How can I score a 6 on GRE writing?Cecilia Sells' answer to What are some essay hacks? If you're talking about a thesis for your masters' degree or a doctoral dissertation, your format is obviously going to be longer than a five-paragraph essay. So how do you expand this format without losing the basic structure? Here is an example: I believe X. X is true because A, B, C, D, and E. F and G are counter-arguments, but they are not important. X is important to the world because of Some Reason.A is important because Reasons. (need more depth? Go into the logic of the reasons in greater detail).B is also important because Other Reasons.C is even more important because Other Other Reasons.D is super important because More Reasons.E is important in some subset of cases of X, and here's why (Even More Reasons).F is a possible counter-argument against my thesis. I believe this counter-argument is not relevant in many cases (or ever) because Whatever Other Reasons.G is an argument that has been raised against X, but it is clearly not true because of Some Obviously Fallacious Reasons.So you see, X is clearly true in most or all cases. Is your paper too short? Think of this structure as fractal. You can do deeper in any area as long as you keep the structure. I know the most about writing humanities papers (not chemistry doctoral theses, for example), and for those, you can go deeper into pretty much any point. For scientific papers, you may need to go deeper into your methodology, or the reasons behind your experiment design, or the existing research you are building on, etc. Don't repeat yourself! This is an opportunity to write a better paper, not just a longer paper. Remember back when your teacher made you write an outline for your papers in school (middle school, high school, maybe even undergrad)? Do that. When your papers were short, it seemed like a waste of time. Now that you're working on a longer paper, with more research and higher standards, it will actually save you time and effort (and earn you a better grade). Write your outline and then start filling in the points as you do your research. Keep going... make that outline super beefy and thick, just full of information. This should be easy, because you don't have to worry about your language or fluidity... it's just a way of organizing your research. Pack in the info. Put little notes to yourself about those interesting thoughts that are part of your logical flow that are not cited. Now, read over your outline. Do you have any weak spots? Do a little more research or a little more thinking, and shore up those places. Does the logic flow in some kind of discernible order? Now is a great time to rearrange things if you need to. Maybe B should really be before A. Put things in the best, most logical order you can, and be consistent with that order throughout your paper. Do you have a huge outline, full of nested bullet points? If so, writing your paper should be super easy. You have everything all organized, ready to go, pre-sorted into sections and paragraphs. Translate those sentence fragments into sentences. Put transitions where they need to go. Don't forget to cite your sources! It's better to be overly careful about citations than to be lax about them. A thesis is strong when it does what it sets out to do. Structure is what allows the point of the writing to shine through. Good grammar and nice words are like icing... they're great, but they have to have a cake to hold them up. Structure is the cake beneath the icing. If your structure is good, your words don't have to be especially fancy to have a good thesis. If your structure is falling apart, all the nice words won't save it.

Below are some 7 easy steps that can help you to write a thesis Before you start, think of your thesis as a case a lawyer has to defend. A thesis statement should explain to your readers the case you wish to make and how you will accomplish that. You can also think of your thesis as a contract. Introducing new ideas the reader is not prepared for may be alienating. An effective thesis statement controls the entire argument. It determines what you cannot say. If a paragraph does not support your thesis, either omit it or change your thesis. Pick a topic that interests you. This must be the first step in writing your paper and your thesis statement because all direction of the paper will depend on what topic you are writing about. Unfortunately, you must ignore this step if the topic is decided for you.Explore your topic. The goal of this step is to find a particular narrow subject in your topic which you can make an argument about. For example, take the topic of computers. There are many aspects of computers that can be expanded on such as hardware, software, and programming. However, vague topics like these do not make good theses. But something more narrow, such as the effects of Steve Jobs on the modern computer industry, allows for a much clearer focus.Know the type, purpose, and audience of the paper. These are usually assigned by the instructor, but even if you get to choose them, you must understand that these will affect your thesis statement considerably. If you are writing a persuasive paper topics, your purpose will be to prove something to a specific group. If you are writing a descriptive paper, your purpose will be to describe something to a specific group. Each of these must be expressed in your thesis somehow.Follow a rigid structure. Knowing the basic formulas will not only keep your thesis within the acceptable length but it will also help you see how your entire argument should be organized. Your thesis should contain two parts:A clear topic or subject matterA brief summary of what you will sayAnother way of looking at a thesis is as a formula, or a pattern, that comfortably holds your ideas:[Something] [does something] because [reason(s)].Because [reason(s)], [something] [does something].Although [opposing evidence], [reasons] show [Something] [does something].The last example includes a counter-argument, which complicates the thesis but strengthens the argument. In fact, you should always be aware of all counter-arguments against your thesis.Doing so will refine your thesis, and also force you to consider arguments you have to refute in your paper 5. Write down your thesis.Writing down a preliminary thesis will get you on the right track and force you to think about it, develop your ideas further, and clarify the content of the paper. You will be able to think about your thesis logically , clearly, and concisely. There are two schools of thought on thesis timing. Some people say you should not write the paper without a thesis in mind and written down, even if you have to alter it slightly by the end. The other school of thought says that you probably won't know where you're going until you get there, so don't write the thesis until you know what it should be. Do whatever seems best to you.6. Analyze your thesis statement once you think you have a final, or working, version. The point is to make sure you avoid making any mistakes that can weaken your thesis. To get a better idea of what to do and what to avoid, consider the following pointers: Never frame your thesis as a question.The job of a thesis is to answer a question, not ask one.A thesis is not a list. If you're trying to answer a specific question, too many variables will send your paper off-focus. Keep it concise and brief.Never mention a new topic that you do not intend to discuss in the paper.Do not write in the first person. Using sentences such as, "I will show...," is generally frowned upon by scholars.Do not be combative. The point of your paper is to convince someone of your position, not turn them off, and the best way to achieve that is to make them want to listen to you. Express an open-minded tone, finding common ground between different views.7. Realize that your thesis does not have to be absolute. Consider it a "working thesis" that's subject to change. As you write your paper you may find that your opinion changes or that your direction has veered slightly. So make sure to continuously re-read your thesis, comparing it to your paper and making the appropriate changes so the two match. Once your paper is finished, go back to your thesis and determine if it needs another revision.

May give a roadmap of the rest of the essay. 6 Easy Steps to Write a Thesis 1. Make a Thesis Question Take your essay topic idea and turn it into a question. Example: divorce. Thesis Question: How does divorce affect children? 2. Brainstorm Answers Write down as many ideas as you can think of. You might want Google search for ideas. Example: Divorce causes children to feel insecure about the future, not do as well in school, feel insecure in relationships, worry about their parents, become bullies or be bullied, have to get along with a new family of siblings, live a lower standard of income, wonder if they caused the divorce. 3. Pick a Thesis Answer Look at your brainstorming and decide your main answer. Example: How does divorce affect children? Divorce causes children to feel insecure. 4. Make a Thesis Road-Map Now go back to your brainstorming. What are the best reasons for your answer? Try to pick at least three. Add these to your thesis. Example: How does divorce affect children? Divorce causes children to feel insecure because they often have a lower standard of living after the divorce, they feel less secure in relationships, and they worry about the future. 5. Add Emphasis Steps 1-4 will make a solid thesis, but if you want to bump it up to the next level you can do two more steps: tell how your view contrasts with other people, and use intensifying transitions like "in reality" or "in fact."

Here are some tips for writing a strong thesis paper. Develop Your Argument. Your thesis is the most important part of your writing. Before you begin writing, you'll want to follow these tips for developing a good thesis statement: Read and compare your sources. What are the main points they make? Do your sources conflict with one another? Don't just summarize your sources' claims; look for the motivation behind their motives.  Draft your thesis. Good ideas are rarely born fully formed. They need to be refined. By committing your thesis to paper, you'll be able to refine it as you research and draft your essay. Consider the other side. Just like a court case, every argument has two sides. You'll be able to refine your thesis by considering the counterclaims and refuting them in your essay. Be Clear and Concise. An effective thesis should answer the reader question, "So what?" It should not be more than a sentence or two. Make a Statement. Although you do want to grab your reader's attention, asking a question is not the same as making a thesis statement. Your job is to persuade by presenting a clear, concise concept that explains both how and why. For research paper help you can choose My Paper Hub.

A thesis statement is that sentence or two that asserts your position on a given issue, specifically, the position that you will be arguing for in your paper. This thesis statement should appear somewhere in the introduction to your paper. It can be the first sentence, although that’s often a rather simplistic and unexciting way to begin your paper. More often, then, a thesis statement should appear at or near the end of the first paragraph or two. The first step in developing a thesis (once you have decided on a topic) is to determine what your position is. To do this, you will need to thoroughly review all the relevant course materials. In most cases, you will have been presented with a number of arguments on both sides of the issue. Carefully analyze and evaluate all those arguments, taking notes as you do. Every paper you write should have a main point, a main idea, or central message. The argument(s) you make in your paper should reflect this main idea. The sentence that captures your position on this main idea is what we call a thesis statement. A thesis statement focuses your ideas into one or two sentences. It should present the topic of your paper and also make a comment about your position in relation to the topic. Your thesis statement should tell your reader what the paper is about and also help guide your writing and keep your argument focused. Your thesis should be limited to what can be accomplished in the specified number of pages. Shape your topic so that you can get straight to the "meat" of it. Being specific in your paper will be much more successful than writing about general things that do not say much. Don't settle for three pages of just skimming the surface. Your thesis statement is no exception to your writing: it needs to be as clear as possible. By being as clear as possible in your thesis statement, you will make sure that your reader understands exactly what you mean.
